title: How to Prepare Yourself for a Big Airsoft Battle

steps.headline: Charge your batteries a day or two before an Airsoft event.
steps.description: (Don't overcharge or undercharge your batteries. A smart charger is highly recommended.)

steps.headline: Clean goggle lenses and let them air dry for a while.
steps.description: Test the resistance by firing point blank. It's better to break your goggles than to lose an eye doing it.

steps.headline: Wash any hydration equipment like canteens or CamelBaks©
Set out your boots, socks and BDU's, including your undergarments and belt.
steps.description: Test out the equipment at least once before you get out on the field in order to get a good feel of it.

steps.headline: Pack your BB's, magazines, batteries and goggles, as well as any headwear and gloves the you will need, into a 'gear bag.'
Pack your replicas and loading equipment into a carrying case.
Pack your gear bag and gun case in the trunk of the car with your load bearing equipment.
Fill hydration equipment.
Get yourself dressed.
Double check that your gear bag, gun case, and load bearing gear are in your trunk.
steps.description: Make sure that you have your goggles and/or face protection.

steps.headline: Print out directions to the field.
Develop your tactics.
steps.description: If you know the geographic layout of your battlefield, find ways you can use it.

steps.headline: Plan along with your teammates.
steps.description: Meet at a friend's house before the battle to run through your plans and make modifications.

steps.headline: Make sure to wear some sort of camouflage!
steps.description: Hunting camo works very well if your are fighting in a forest or in the woods, however airsoft is a Military Simulation sport, so wear some sort of military camouflage. If possible get a mask or vest. They really help to lessen the pain of an airsoft pellet.

methods.name: Some extra items you may want to pack:

steps.headline: FRS Radio
Red shop rag (Common method of indicating you're out);
Baby wipes and lint free cloth;
Sealed food, like granola bars or beef jerky;
Knee pads;
Rope or 'Para' cord;
Duct tape;
Multi-tools, also known as Leatherman;
Multi-head screwdriver (Should include common size Phillips, flat and torx bits);
First aid kit;
Whistle in case of emergencies;
AAA, AA and 9V batteries;
Sunscreen and/or bug spray; socks;
Gun jamming rod.
